questiontext.text:
Exercise

If \(\displaystyle{n=\frac{1}{2L}\sqrt{\frac{E}{d}}}\) and \(L, E\) and \(d\) can be measured correct to within \(1\)%, how accurate is the calculated value of \(n\)?

The maximum percentage error in \(n\) is [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]%.

generalfeedback.text:
We are given the funtcion \(\displaystyle{n=\frac{1}{2L}\sqrt{\frac{E}{d}}}\) and \(L, E, d\) are subject to percentage relative errors of \({@error_L@} \%\).

First, find \(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial L},\) \(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial E}\) and \(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial d}\)

\(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial L} = \displaystyle {@n_L@}\)

\(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial E} = \displaystyle {@n_E@}\)

\(\dfrac{\partial n}{\partial d} = \displaystyle {@n_d@}\)

Now we write down the expression of \( \delta n .\)

\[ \begin{align} \left|\delta n \right|_{\text{max}} & \simeq \left| \frac{\partial n}{\partial L} \right| \left| \delta L \right|+ \left| \frac{\partial n}{\partial E} \right| \left| \delta E \right| + \left| \frac{\partial n}{\partial d} \right| \left| \delta d \right| \\ & \simeq \left| {@n_L@} \right| \left| \delta L \right| + \left| {@n_E@} \right| \left| \delta E \right| + \left| {@n_d@} \right| \left| \delta d \right| \end{align}\]

Hence we write down an expression for the percentage relative error in \(f\):

\[ \begin{align} \dfrac{\delta n}{n} \times 100 & \simeq \left| {@n_L@} \times 2L \sqrt{\frac{d}{E}} \, \delta L \times 100 \right| + \left| {@n_E@} \times 2L \sqrt{\frac{d}{E}} \, \delta E \times 100 \right| + \left| {@n_d@} \times 2L \sqrt{\frac{d}{E}} \, \delta d \times 100 \right| \\ & \simeq \left| {@n1@} \delta L \times 100 \right| + \left| {@n2@} \delta E \times 100 \right| + \left| {@n3@} \delta d \times 100 \right| \end{align}\]

The percentage relative errors of \(L,E, d\) are \({@error_L@} \%\) so:

\[ \frac{\delta L}{L} = {@error_L@}, \quad \frac{\delta E}{E} = {@error_E@}, \quad \frac{\delta d}{d} = {@error_d@} \]

Substituting them into the previous relation we find:
\[\dfrac{\delta v}{v} \times 100 \simeq  {@error_L@} +\frac{{@error_E@}}{2} + \frac{{@error_d@}}{2} ={@ta1@} \%\]

Alterantive method:

Take logarithms of both sides \[\ln n = -\ln 2 - \ln L + \frac{1}{2} \ln E - \frac{1}{2} \ln d\]

So \(\displaystyle \frac{\delta n}{n} = -\frac{\delta L}{L}+ \frac{\delta E}{2E} - \frac{\delta d}{2d}\)

The maximum percentage error in \(n\) is therefore \[v=\left|\frac{\delta L}{L}\right|+\left|-\frac{\delta E}{2E}\right| + \left|-\frac{\delta d}{2d}\right|= {@error_L@} +\frac{{@error_E@}}{2} + \frac{{@error_d@}}{2} = {@ta1@} \% \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
